Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the text from my girlfriend: “Can we talk? I feel like you’re avoiding me.” My heart sank. We’d just had a small argument about our weekend plans, and I knew she expected me to call and sort things out. But downstairs, I could hear my stepdad calling everyone to the table. Tonight was our first family dinner since my mom remarried, and I was supposed to be there, smiling, making an effort to bond with my new step-siblings. My mom had made it clear how important this was to her, and I didn’t want to let her down. But I also couldn’t ignore my girlfriend, not when she was upset and needed reassurance. I felt pulled in two directions—one part of me wanting to be the supportive boyfriend, the other not wanting to disappoint my family. My phone buzzed again, and my stepdad’s voice grew louder, calling my name. I stood frozen at the top of the stairs, torn between the two worlds, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
